Posts.Content:
Femara has been around for some time.   I don't know if it was approved or not, but a friend whose breast cancer went elsewhere was put on it immediately - and that was 10 years ago, and it did a good job for her.  She's still here, and she's about
 75 now.

Posts.Content: Heard from Shelley today that Fran Berg had posted on the iv board that she has a recurrence.  Those of you who were out in Louisville remember that we went to her home one night and were so graciously welcomed.  What fun we had.

Posts.Content:
Sweet Cathi, I so hate this disease. I am very, very sorry to hear about
 the new spots on your spine. Also, hate like heck that you will have to be on chemo again. Hope that it is easy on you like it apparently was with Jackie. If you're up to calls, let me know. I know that sometimes we just don't want to continuously talk about
 our health issues - just want to forget about
 it.
As I'm sure you are well aware, I'm not a good correspondent; but even when I don't post, write or call, you are in my thoughts and prayers.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Here we go AGAIN......Grrrrrrrrr

Posts.Content:
Patty, dear girl, I check in every week to see what's happening, and here you are MOVING out of NC. What's happening? Hope it's good, good. Have you seen Patti or Barbara recently? I've lost touch with everyone, it seems. I'm 8 years out now, started Femara two years ago and stopped it a couple of months ago. Onc said she supported my decision. Even though I was taking the calcium and Vit. D supplements as prescribed, was having bone deterioration that could really, really be seen from year to year on the bone density studies. Keep an eagle eye on that when you go on it. It seems I was having 100% certainty of bone destruction for a drug that gave me 3% help. Hope I'm never in the situation of second guessing myself!
Best of luck on your move and continued GOOD health. If you still have your old e-mail address, I'll send you my new one -- on Roadrunner now.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Need to find a new onc....anyone in Philadelphia area?

Posts.Content:
All good thoughts and vibes coming your way, including all things "crossable" crossed.
Also hope that Tavish wasn't too traumatized at the vet. My cats hate to go.
And like sweet Cathi, tell us all about
 the wedding plans. I need some romance in my life!
Love, Glenda
P.S. Particularly, hope there's no haggling over your selling price.
Posts.Title: Clutter: Need positive vibes, everyone!

Posts.Content:
Dear Cathi,
Sorry that all this bad stuff is happening to you. If your boss is your "old" boss from the time of the Texas trip, then he should be doubly ashamed. Get the money if you can, and maybe you ought to consider going on disability. All unnecessary aggravation and worry is not good for you, and the job falls in that category. Don't feel bad about
 taking disability or anything else that the government will deliver. After all you have been paying for it for however many years you've worked, and so have the rest of us. I'll give you part of mine! You'll find lots of fun things to do with your time away from State Farm.
Hope you had a great time at the wedding and that you and Luci will have a wonderful visit. Take care of yourself.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Having a bad day ......

Posts.Content:
Dak, welcome to the board, but sorry about
 the bc. I just read your new member info, and wondered how the bone scan and other tests turned out. I know you started chemo last week and hope you are not feeling too bad this week. Good luck with treatments, and hope all scans and tests were negative.
Glenda
Posts.Title: treatment question

Posts.Content:
Frayda, sorry to hear about
 this, but Femara is GOOD news. I do not (thank you, God) have mets, but started taking Femara after I had finished my 5 years of Tamox. I'm almost eight years out from diagnosis.
One of my good friends had bc lung mets, and they put her on Femara about
 four years ago. She has had some of the spots GO AWAY, and those that are left are not growing or are smaller. 
All good thoughts to your sister and you.
Hugs, Glenda
Posts.Title: My sister has bc mets to the lung....

Posts.Content:
Ditto to above. Except for the dang needle, nothing to it. I was able to see my skeleton while the test was going on, which I found awesome, even if a little frightening. I saw my right ankle really glow, and was able to say I broke it when I was 27, so I had something to compare to. I happened to know this tech and maybe that's why he'd let me look, but maybe everyone above saw theirs too. You will have to wait several hours after the shot so that you'll be sure to glow. I did kind of hate thinking there was radioactive material of some sort being injected into this old body, but so is the nature of the bc beast.
Good luck, 
Glenda
Posts.Title: Bone Scan this Thursday, what should I expect?

Posts.Content:
Dearest Cathi,
So glad you're home. I'm praying that the docs will come up with a plan that doesn't make you feel so very bad. Please don't give up. Okay? I love you.
Glenda
Posts.Title: Home again.....

Posts.Content:
Janis, start using the gel now. I put aloe vera on after each session, and it was only the last boost that I had any discomfort under my arm, and that went away fast.
Someone else posted about
 comparing side effects. Other than MAYBE a burn, there might not be any side effects. I had none. I was so thrilled to be through chemo, that I don't think much could have bothered me. But try not to anticipate anything. You might just glide right through. Hope so anyway.
Posts.Title: Just started rads with week

Posts.Content:
Good morning, dear lady,
Glad the bone density study was good, but the other sucks. I'm still think Femara has some side effects that produce joint problems. Of course, since Femara shuts down all estrogen, maybe it just kicks the aging process into overdrive!! Another thing maybe we weren't told about!! Oh well, *itch, *itch. I am approaching my eight year NED mark and I guess I should shut up about anything else. LOL. Anyway, SSDD.
Remember we can't fall apart completely - you haven't visited me yet in N.C. I'm just a half a day from Atlanta!!
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Got my test results today

Posts.Content:
That's wonderful, Cathi, on both the stable and the tm drop - big drop, too!!! Really happy for you and send you lots of love.
Glenda
Posts.Title: Finally some good news...

Posts.Content:
My onc started them after I was five years out. She said (Duke Cancer Center doc) that she had just started using them because of some study or other re early detection of recurrence, blah, blah; but only used them on patients five years out.
However, I'm going to ask at my next annual appt. in Aug. if they really are necessary, because I've read a LOT on tumor markers in the past year and it seems that the majority opinion is that, yes, they would detect recurrence early, but detecting recurrences early plays no part in prognosis - so my question is, why have them? I'll have that answer this August.
All this research on tumor markers occurred when mine went from their usual 34 to 49. Had to go back in, give more blood and retest. This time it came back at my usual numbers. Of course, I asked why the increase if not cancer related, and, guess what, labs make mistakes, the blood could have gotten contaminated, it could have coagulated quickly and --- anyway, lots of reasons.
My best to you, Glenda
Posts.Title: Tumor Markers, another question or two

Posts.Content: Interesting discussion. I had one dot only. I think it was because before I began treatments had to go over to Duke be positioned using all kinds of lasers (looked like a laser light show) and when I was positioned exactly where they wanted me -- by the way, I was laying on some big plastic thing -- they poured some quick hardening foam stuff around me in that exact position. Each time I went for rads I was placed in this mold on the table which apparently put me in the exact position they wanted me. It even included my arm in an upward out-streached position. Strange to see that 6 foot cast every time I went. There was always some small adjustment I'd make, but the whole treatment never took over five minutes, so suited me. When I had finished treatment, the sweet but silly techs asked if I'd like to take the d*mn thing home with me. Imagine my response! LOL Glenda
Posts.Title: Question about rad dots

Posts.Content:
Jackie, glad the Abraxane is working. And big congrats on the Master's degree. So glad I got to meet you in person. You're a lovely woman. Also, as I have told you many times before, you were the first person to post to me when I began posting on iv six years ago. 
You gave me hope. Thank you, and prayers for a clean scan.
L+H, Glenda

Posts.Title: Finally home from the hospital.....

Posts.Content:
Julie, you will be in my thoughts. Tests are always the pits. I know that all centers/docs seem to do things differently, but why scans now? Are your tumor markers up? What is the reasoning? I'm coming up on 8 years NED and other than at the beginning have had no scans. In the bc world of paranoia, I worry SHOULD I have had scans. It just never stops, does it? All good thoughts that all will be well for you, and we have this conversation when you go for your TEN year scans.
Empathetic hugs, Glenda
Posts.Title: Nervous about 5 year scans...

Posts.Title: Bev, thinking of you and...

Posts.Content:
Big, BIG congrats. I remember you coming on the old iv board. It seems like a life time ago. You're a wonderful, caring person. A toast to 99 more! I'm sneaking up on 8 years myself soon, and for you "newbies" I had a 2.5 cm lump, 2 pos. nodes, mastectomy, chemo (CMF) and radiation, tamox for five years and now on Femara.
Love you, lady and hope you and your mom have big travel plans this spring. Come on down to NC and visit me sometimes.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: A day to celebrate.....m

Posts.Content:
Add my congratulations, Mary K. My aunt had Down's, and was a most special person, so very sweet. She was born in 1918 and my grandmother was told she wouldn't survive, but my grandmother, already mother of eight, had a different plan. I am happy to be able to write her name in remembrance, Helen Claire Frazier. She lived to be 72 and was a blessing to all our family.
I know your sweet baby girl will bless your family's life.

Posts.Title: Bone scan last week...

Posts.Content:
Hey, girl,
What a lovely post to read. Yeah, I remember your second diagnosis. That was a bad time in a lot of ways. So very glad that your tests were so ho-hum. Let's hope the Arimidex will treat you better. Femara is kicking my knee joints BAD, so I'm going to talk to my onc about switching also. Tell me about this stopping everything after 10 years. What did your onc tell you about that? In my pre-bc days, I used to be so brave and fearless, but I wonder if I'll ever feel comfortable again just hanging out there without meds (sigh).
Anyway, congrats and love to you - Glenda
Posts.Title: Got the results from my tests today.......

Posts.Content:
Frank, I think the secret is getting the swelling down, and the pain lessens considerably - re my experience. My suggestion would be to keep the ice applied as long as she can, take a break and then put it back on. It's just one of those things that she's going to have to work through. Seems there's nothing easy about this whole disease process.
Good luck and praises to you for being such a devoted husband.
Stay positive and strong, Glenda
Posts.Title: how much pain and swelling?

Posts.Content:
Prayers that all will turn out well, and glad the test wasn't bad. Happy belated anniversary. Waiting with you for results.
L&H Glenda
Posts.Title: Prayers Tomorrow

Posts.Content:
Dear, dear Luci,
I had the "cystoscope thing" done a couple of years ago. During the same time I also had a CT of the kidneys and bladder. I had a little blood in my urine and was also urinating more frequently - hence all the tests! The cystoscope wasn't so bad, and it was reassuring to know there was no bladder cancer. So - o, after all these things, the answer was that I was suffering from an irritated bladder. They could see that it was somewhat inflammed by the cystoscope. The reason for the irritated bladder was our friend chemotherapy - surprise. I think I mentioned !!! that to them from the get-go.
I was very uninformed at the beginning of my chemo treatment and didn't drink a lot of water to flush everything (wasn't told to either). So, hope this helps some on the board who are just beginning their therapy to drink, drink, drink. It might have happened even with the flushing procedure, so they told me, but I'll bet dollars to donuts that the flushing out will help a lot.
I'll be keeping you in my thoughts, as always.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Info. re: cytoxan....

Posts.Content:
You're right, Luci, I have that address. This is not her home address. I wouldn't give that out, but it is the one that will get our expressions of sympathy and support to her. Elizabeth Edwards in care of Senator John Edwards' senate office: 25 Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, D.C 20510.
The elephant sitting in the corner analogy was right on, Luci. My husband's comment was "I'll bet he was saying things to himself like 'forget about the election, just let her live.'" That's what he said he would be thinking anyway.
My comment was that maybe she hadn't found time to have a mammogram lately. When you're very busy and feeling pretty good, sometimes you just don't remember to do the right things for your health. That was my story anyway. It had been FOUR years since I had had a mammo when I was diagosed.
There has been lots and lots of reporting on bc and how to catch it early and treatment options and docs coming on talking about new research since her diagnosis hit the news. Maybe out of her pain something good re research, etc. will happen.
I cry as I write this. Stay strong Elizabeth and John and God's mercy on you.
L&H Glenda
Posts.Title: Elizabeth Edwards' Mailing Address

Posts.Content:
Could there be a better Christmas present than b-9???? Don't think so. Yippee from sunny North Carolina!
Hugs, Glenda
Posts.Title: Yoohoo! for benign results!!!

Posts.Content:
I'm sorry you are in such a down period, but I think we all probably experience what you're experiencing. Hoping things get better for you soon.
NOW, what an interesting discussion about aches and pains, chemo and Femara. I had the chemo and am taking the Femara now and have been having major problems with my knees. I was blaming it on being 56 and maybe it is, but I remember well when my parents were 56 and they didn't have this knee thing. My Mom had arthritis in her hands later in life but not at 56. Maybe it is the Femara. I'll surely run that by my onc. Of course, I blame a lot of things on chemo and rightly so. It changed my immune system. All of a sudden I get warts??? All of a sudden I sometimes break out in hives??? All of a sudden I am alergic to things I was never allergic to before??? And when I was taking Tamox for 5 years, I had leg cramps with some frequency, and since I've been off that for almost 2 years, I NEVER have them now. There must be a correlation.
Everyone speak up. Are others of you younger, my age or older having similar problems?
Anyway, hope I hear from some of you. And I'm glad I could get on the Board. This morning I was told our Board didn't exist when I tried to log on. Had to send out the emergency emails to MaryK and Jo-Ann!
Hugs to all, Glenda
Posts.Title: new to message board, need to vent.............

Posts.Content:
Luci,
Finally got the card I wanted to send last night, and will mail it to you today. Read in our local papers that the nodes were clean!!
They also gave a new address: Elizabeth Edwards, P.O. Box 5428, Washington 20013.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Elizabeth Edwards' cards....

Posts.Content:
Dearest Jo-Ann,
All my info was correct, so I didn't respond. I hope that was right. I have been in a work "fog" lately and could have misunderstood everything!
Thanks for doing this. You and Mikki have always been so good about this.
The BIG thing though is that you are home and on the mend. Be careful from now on, I mean it!
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Further on the name & address list........

Posts.Content:
Tamaralynn, you may not have a plan (might not need one) but you sure are on the right, positive track. This disease turned me on to Relay for Life, the ACS major event. In hopefully helping others, I ended up helping myself. You're right, the possibilities are endless. I've made so many new friends in my volunteer efforts; and like the friends I've met and made on this board and others, they are friends for life. I've got to admit that I was mad at God at first, but who am I to understand his plans? But I know he has one for me, and I'm just along for the ride doing the best I can. You will too.
Good luck, Glenda
Posts.Title: nervous the night before

Posts.Content:
Having a hysterectomy didn't affect MY sex drive when I was 36, but I don't think anything would have then!! I had my cervix removed too. Am I about to learn something new at 56? Did my cervix play some important role??? I thought it was G spots and stuff. LOL
Best of luck with it all. Stef. I had the "big" cut for various reasons, but that's one where it you don't have to be cut, don't be cut! That one was painful for a while, and no driving for six weeks - not good.
Take care, Glenda
Posts.Title: Surgery date for ooph and....

Posts.Content:
Great news! So pleased for you on all counts.
Hugs, Glenda
Posts.Title: Good News!!!

Posts.Content:
Nothing pathetic about your post, dear Bev. I have to believe that grief lessens over time, but I know in my case, it's always lurking around. I think that we begin to really heal when we wake up in the morning, and the first thoughts are NOT about the fact that someone we love has died. That has been my experience, anyway.
And big congrats on the 10 years!! I celebrate my yearly diagnosis anniversary with more fanfare than my birthday.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: Re: my last pathetic post...

Posts.Content:
Happy, happy birthday, dear Luci. I hope all your birthday wishes come true. Enjoy the beginning of another year for a wonderful person.
Love, Glenda
P.S. Thanks Cathi for letting us know. Love you, too.
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday to our sweet Luci......!!!!

Posts.Content:
Susan, my heartfelt sympathies to you and your family. Mary was a special person. She and her DH were the very first people I met at our very first meeting in Cincy. She was sitting on the sofa at the Inn when Peg Gray and I walked in. Peg had met her and knew who she was. She was excited about meeting everyone, and I was excited about meeting her.
Along with the others from this board who met her, I'll always remember her. Rest in peace, Mary.
Hugs, Glenda
Posts.Title: MaryT's Passing

Posts.Content: Julie, all positive thoughts and crossable body parts crossed (prayers too) that checkup was normal. And I agree that it doesn't get easier at each visit, but the longer out in remission, for me, and hopefully for you, it has gotten easier NOT thinking about it in between. God Bless - L&H Glenda
Posts.Title: Onc. visit on Thursday....m

Posts.Content:
I called her yesterday afternoon, and she sounds like her "old" self. Told me what MK related, especially the part where the antibiotics seem to be kicking in. It was good to hear her voice.
L&H, Glenda
Posts.Title: Jo-Ann sends you a message.............

Posts.Content:
...and thanks to you all for your good wishes. I stop in weekly for updates, but those of you who know me know how many "hats" I'm wearing these days in the work department. I haven't figured out if I do all this for the money or to just stay so busy so as not to think about bc!! My bd was a good day. I actually didn't even think about work, was taken to dinner, received nice 
 surprises, and dd and sil are taking me out to dinner tonight. I LOVE getting older now - just LOVE it!!
Had my yearly onc exam the end of August. All the blood work, exam and vital signs were very, very good. Went skipping home, and a week later, get the call from the onc saying, "Your tumor markers are elevated"!!! He thinks there's some lab mistake. Back in the next day for repeat of test. Ask my friends the nurses if the lab has been wrong before - long pause - and then, "No." I spiral down, down. Ask for their prayers, and doggone if we don't have a "prayer session" right then and there. One of the nurses asked in her prayer that I be able to enjoy the upcoming Labor Day weekend without dwelling on this news. God was listening and I was able to put it from my mind. Came back home Saturday afternoon, listened to my phone messages, and there was one from one of the onc nurses. They had put a rush on the lab work, she was there on Sat. administering chemo to someone, saw the results were in and here is what her message said. "Old buddy, this is Teresa. God was listening. Your tumor markers are back to what they've always been. I repeat, markers are NORMAL. (Laughs) We love you. Bye." What can I say?? Although I am one year older, I feel 20 years younger. 
 
Love to you all and in honor of Connie - Seven years and 1 month - Glenda
Posts.Title: Thank you for remembering, Cathi...

Posts.Content:
Janice, so sorry you're having to go through all this, but don't lose hope. Praying that you will soon begin to regain more and more strength and that the new treatments will be easier on you and they will work.
Big Hug, Glenda
Posts.Title: Here's an update on me.....

Posts.Content:
Sweet Cathi, I only knew that Aromasin was involved in controlling estrogen in some way. I looked it up on the net, and this is one of the sites that was pretty informative.
my.webmd.com/hw/drug/d04461a1.asp?bn=aromasin
Hope that will help you a little. Is there any chance of more rads to help in the pain? This all just sucks. You're a real trooper though, God bless. You're always in my thoughts and prayers. I hate to bother you with calls. I remember all too well that my phone used to ring constantly with loving questions about how I was and though I appreciated them greatly, it was always when I had stopped thinking about this dang disease for just a bit, and I would crash again. (sigh)
Love you - Glenda
Posts.Title: Aromasin.......Questions....

Posts.Content:
Great news! As Jessie said, EKG is piece of cake. I too look askance at docs who say "cured." Though in my heart, I pray it's so. Nail polish remover will take off the glue - if you can stand the smell!!
Glenda
Posts.Title: Onc. gave me the "all clear"....

Posts.Content:
Becky, glad your day was wonderful. And your daughter's birthday is the same as mine! Libras are interesting people. You must remember to WATCH HER CAREFULLY!!! LOL 
 My mother could have bent your ear about girls born on 10-9!!
Mega prayers that the chemos will do their magic. And remember 10 years from now when DD gets her license, that we Libra girls drive like "the wind."
Love you, Becky!
Glenda
Posts.Title: Have to share with you the best day----

Posts.Content:
Yippee!!! And the second opinion is the only way to go. As always, your take-charge of your own health mode is inspiring and educational. Recommending surgery without even seeing the pictures is astounding to me. Here's a thought - have you noticed that your pants or skirts have gotten looser?? Maybe it's just a little hip fat moving down! LOL - a good thing. 
So happy for you, dear Luci.
Love, Glenda
Posts.Title: MRI results are in....

Posts.Content:
Glenda, 55, North Carolina. Diagosed 9/97, er/pr+++, stage IIb, 2 pos. nodes, mastectomy, CMF for 6 months, radiation, tamoxifen for 5 years, now taking femara as recurrence preventative, 6yrs 7mos NED (knock wood).
Married for 34 years, 1 daughter (26). Very active in local ACS Relay for Life
Posts.Title: ROLL CALL name, age, state and any other info to share
